Award.AbstractNarration:
When massive stars (those with at least 8 times the Sun's mass) reach the end of their existence they can explode releasing large quantities of heavy elements that enrich the next generation of stars. Modeling these core-collapse supernovae and their ejecta requires complex and well resolved three-dimensional numerical simulations running on large computers. The abundances of heavy elements (known as 'metals' to astronomers) has increased from none in the very first stars formed after the Big Bang to the Solar-like composition found in recently formed stars in the nearby universe. Supernovae are dependent on the pre-explosion structure of the star, which is dependent on both the stellar mass and the amount of 'metals' in the star. To cover the variation through cosmic time in the stars that explode as supernovae we will compute three well-resolved 3D supernova simulations for low, medium, and high mass exploding stars at each of three 'metallicities' representing the build-up of heavy elements from the primordial zero metallicity to solar metallicity. From these simulations the investigators will extract the properties of the explosions and their ejecta to get a better understanding of the nature of the supernova mechanism and its contributions to the evolution of galaxies through cosmic time.

The investigators will use their multi-physics Chimera code, which includes neutrino radiation hydrodynamics with modern neutrino-matter interactions, general relativistic corrections to multi-pole self-gravity, a dense matter nuclear equation of state, and built-in nuclear networks to compute evolving abundances in the non-equilibrium layers outside the iron-core and in the ejecta. The three simulations of 1-degree resolution will be computed at each metallicity from low (about 10 solar mass), medium (15 solar mass), and high (about 25 solar mass) progenitors found to explode in similar 2D (axisymmetric) simulations. Simulations will be computed at zero, solar, and low metallicities and both direct and post-processed nucleosynthesis will be computed for the ejecta. Additional analyses will produce gravitational wave and neutrino signals that directly probe the central supernova engine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project seeks to improve our understanding of the explosive deaths of massive stars (those at least 8 times the mass of the sun) and their contribution to the chemical elements that make-up everything on our planet by making high-quality (all necessary physics included), well resolved, supercomputer models of stellar explosions. We examined explosions from stars that span the expected range throught the history of the Universe, from lower to higher star mass and the variation in chemical elements that accumulate throughout cosmic history.

Part of understanding the supernova mechanism is to understand how choices in computer modelling impacts the results. As part of this study we computed models with lower resolution (comparible to other published works) to understand how well resolved our models must be. We found that the lower resolution models had delayed and weaker explosions. The complex behavior of the material between the shock and the collapsed core (primary image) is turbulent and convective. We also examined the details of turbulent convection in a very-high resolution model on a "wedge" of the stellar core. These models show that as expected turbulence in the convective region that drives the explosion is better captured in high-resolution models, as expected. From these studies we can be reasonably assured that the results of the main study (with 1-degree resolution in angle) are not overly affected by "underresolution" and that future studies need not be hyperfocused on acheiving the highest possible resolutions, so long as basic standards are met.

From our main mass and composition study, we found a previously unseen event during stellar collapse in one model and by using a large network in the same model were able to compute directly the production of the important radioisotope Ti-44 (one of a handfull of isotopes directly observed by space telescopes) and the rare neutron-rich form of calcium, Ca-48. By using a large nuclear reaction network in the model for the lightest of the stars examined, we were able to directly trace the formation of these (and other) isotopes in the ejecta accurately. Previous work had either used tracer particles to sample the outflow, and/or simpler nuclear networks that can't capture all of the necessary reactions that occur when these (and other) isotopes form (or omit them completely). This has a strong impact of the computed production of Ti-44. Ca-48 has an uncertain origin and had been previously found in models of the lightest stars that explode when their cores collapse by processing sample tracers. By including a sufficient nuclear network directly in our cacluation we are able to positively identify such stars as sources of Ca-48 and predict its production.

When these models are fully analyzed, the results will be used to understand the build up of elements made by stars to the orgiinal (hydrogen + helium) composition formed in the Big Bang; to understand future observations of nearby supernova explosions detected by underground neutrino detectors and gravitational wave observatories; and to better understand the complex and fascinating way in which the massive stars end their existances.
